rich, subtly complex, very earthy, oily.  not overly astringent or charcoal.

500 ml bottle from Belmont Party Supply.  Pours a really dark brown, opaque and almost black, with a small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, brown sugar, hops, mixed fruits, syrup, vanilla, and cola.  Flavor of chocolate, brown sugar, sweet roasted malts, syrup, vanilla, cola, dark fruits, and mineral notes.  Medium-full bodied, with a metallic mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  This is an unusual, but pretty good imperial stout.  Seek it out, its worth the low price tag.

Bottle.  Although the pour seems fairly thin for the style, with just a wisp of a head, the aroma on this could peel paint off the walls.  This drinks with all the fullness one would expect from an Imperial Stout, rich with dark chocolate and cream.  A delicious option for dessert.  (#3883, 4/11/2010)

11.2 oz bottle:  Very little of the light beige head sticks around the edge of the beer on the glass.  The color could be a bit darker for me, but its still a nicedeep mohogany.  Aromas of caramel, dark raisiny fruit, dark chocolate w/ lots of cacoa , figs, toasty and bready malts.  Zero hop aromas... Nice and to my liking in an imperial stout.  A bit of aged toffee aroma.  Sweet with a freshly cracked base malt aroma as it warms.  A touch of roast and chocolate malts aroma.  The flavor is much the same...  Starts sweet, finishes a bit on the dry side and well balanced.  Dark fruits with raisins and fig flavors.  Malt flavor is sort of hidden behind the fruity flavors, but toffee and caramel with toasty flavors.  Aftertaste is roasty and chocolate with a touch of earthy hops.  A bit aged, but still good in its own right.  Medium bodied, could be a bit more full for me.  Lower CO2 fits into my liking for this type of beer.  Smooth overall but a touch dry at the finish in the mouth.  Not my favorite imperial stout, but a solid beer!
Bottle from De Molen Brouwerij. This is a fantastic Imperial Stout. Pitch black beer, tan head, taste of coffee, long lasting aftertaste of chocolate.

Bottle, 11.2oz. Nice mellow mocha aroma which is backed up on the tongue, a nice velvety chocolate flavor with a small roast hint. Pours a thinnish black with little head, finish is a tad watery as well, but fits the overall profile and leaves a trace aftertaste behind.
50 cl bottle. Very dark brown body with tan head. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.

The aroma is hearty malts with sour and coffee notes. There is a nice hearty creamy tan head with a rich and dark roasted color, almost ruby red black.  The hearty flavor is so smooth on the palate. There are sour notes, but not bitter at all. The malts are a little smoky as well, almost like a scotch ale, but as I said....really smooth.
Bottle. Solic black pour, creamy tanned head. Aroma is strong liquorice, peat and coffee. Flavour is bitter peat and coffee and bittersweet liquorice. Long lasting peat and coffee flavour.

Bottle, thanks for sharing dEnk! Pours pitch black with a thin tan head that laces. Aroma of licorice, spices and bread. Flavor starts sweet but evolves into quite a bitter finish. Creamy, thick bodied texture.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 Bottle:
Pretty big light brown head disappears quick.
Beer is black-ish brown.
Taste is completely different from smell. Rich taste, dark, roasted and a little bit of fruit is what comes to mind first. 
Its less bitter than other Imperial Stouts. Not much of a body, though I had worse Imperial Stouts.
Even a small touch of fruity ingredients is to be discovered.
The taste is better than everything else, but not too great since a bitter taste of roasted ingredients is far away.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Pours from the small bottle an dark black, opaque and a small but dense deep tan head. Aroma has a strong raisin, toffee, chocolate, mild licorice and a mild sour, roasted malt ending. Flavor has a strong chocolate and roasted barley note first with these fading to a more subdue raisin fruity flavor later in the tasting. The beer is very clean on your palate with a light body and very fine low carbonation that aid in the retention of the great head. Overall a very nice imp. stout. The roasted body really carries an awesome flavor with a very good balance so that all the flavors and aromas can be detected.

11.2 ounce bottle from State Line Liquors. ABV is a little low for a typical imperial stout, which is a very welcome thing. This bottle has at least one year of age on it, but no vintage markings. Pours a deep, dark brown color with ruby highlights. Almost no head to speak of. Aroma of toffee, roasted malts, smoke, leather, a dusty note, caramel and a bit of fruitiness. Im really digging it. The taste is roasted malts, cocoa, chocolate, caramel, smoke, leafy hops. Thin-medium bodied. A tasty and truly enjoyable beer.

From bottle thx to Piet Salomez.
Taste @ beer-taste-lessons 06.02.2010.
A black color, with a beige head. Aroma roasted malts and coffee. 
Medium body. Taste sweet, roasted malts , dark fruit, dry bitter coffeetouch. Dry bitter aftertaste.
11th November 2008. Low carbonation opaque black stout. Lots of rich chocolate was well as minerally tangy malt. Not overly thick and goes down very easily. No bitterness or dryness.

Pours a one finger light brown head that fades slowly to a ring, leaving traces of lace. Black color, no highlights.  Roasted/burnt chocolate nose. Light carbonation and medium-heavy bodied. Flavor follows the nose with roasted/burnt chocolate. Nice imperial stout. Worth trying even at $7.00 for a 330ml bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

Black colored brew, nice head and texture. Aroma is milk chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor is a bit thin, but got nice sweet chocolate tones and roasted malty bitterness, some licorice and coffee. Nice balance between sweetness and bitterness.

Deep brown w/ a big tan head of mixed bubbles that leaves little spots of lace. Nose consists of milk chocolate, mild roast coffee and a sweet nutty overtone. Flavor is pretty consistent w/ that though w/ a bit of tartness that implies raisins and dark fruit. Vigorous carbonation lightens what would otherwise be a medium bodied mouthfeel. Finished w/ a balancing note of coffee-like bitterness and a just a twinge of alcohol.

Tasty foreign stout, possesses a sour flavor that adds to the overall impression of the beer.  The appearance looked a little thin for a foreign stout, but again, the flavor is pretty tasty.  Has a good malty aroma.  Overall, a competent stout.

Somewhat thin looking dark brown pour with a tan head. First scent is sour, followed by sweet malt. Flavor is similar, first sour and then a very nice burst of roasted malt, the aftertaste is somewhat smokey. Body is a little thin for an imperial, but a good beer non the less.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2010 Bottle.  pours black with a small, tight, tan head.  Initial smell has a lot of molases, figs, prunes, and cocoa.  As it warms, there is a unexpected weird cherry, vanilla,  and bourbon note.  flavor is coffee, earthy milk chocolate, roasted malts, and toast.  mouthfeel is a bit then. leaves the lips sticky.  low carbonation.  I can see this going pretty well with deserts, as the commercial description suggests.  A lot of really nice fruit, chocolate, and espresso type notes come through.  Besides the thin mouthfeel and somewhat stale nature of the beer, this is pretty great.

A black colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of roasted malts with some chocolate and coffee beans. There is also some dark fruit. The taste is dry bitter with roasted malts some chocolate with hints of coffee and a little sweetness of fruits. The aftertaste is dry bitter with a little sweet.
Dark brown, coffee-like color; mild aroma of roasted barley and hints of liquorice; medium body, quite a harsh mouthfeel; flavor is roasted barley, coffee, liquorice; finish is dry and bitter.

A deep dark stout with a thick moka head. Aroma of bitter chocolate, dark fruits, plums, treacle,  molasses, and some meaty notes. In mouth, a good bitter chocolate with funky acid points, light cinnamon, a bit thin in mouth, not the greatest IS but fairly decent. Bieropholie import, BB Nov. 2014, tasted Jan. 4 2010.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2010 Well my friend Sweet Jay took me to that video arcade in town, right, and they dont speak English there, so Jay got into a fight and hes all, "Hey quit hasslin me cuz I dont speak French" or whatever! And then the guy said something in Paris talk, and Im like, "Just back off!" And theyre all, "Get out!" And were like, "Make me!" It was cool. .. . pours a dark brown-black .. . excellent roast levels .. . amazingly smooth .. . would love to try more from this brewer ..

Bottle: &nbsp Surprisingly the color was only of a dark cola, not black nor opaque, thin sudsy beige head, falls quickly, leaving minor lacing. &nbsp Doesnt look like much of an Imperial Stout. &nbsp Heavy roasted malt nose, 

slight soy. &nbsp Sweet yet biting roasted malt flavors on the tongue. &nbsp Much like black coffee, tiz a bit dry. &nbsp A little chalky on the back, with some bittersweet chocolate rounding it out. &nbsp Not half bad, even if a bit 

dry and chalky. &nbsp Not as full in body or mouthfeel as other examples. &nbsp Could pass as a really robust porter, except for the fact that its really really roasty. &nbsp I tend to think Imperial Stouts as being a bit heavier, which 

this one is not. &nbsp Swedish you say? &nbsp Tiz clean on the exit. &nbsp Lingering roastiness. &nbsp Not a big stout by any means, but for a moderate Imperial Stout it is quite tasty.

Dark brown, close to black with a small brown head. Aroma is roasted espresso like malts, light minerals and light chocolate. Flavour is smooth chocolate and coffe with a balanced bitter ending that has notes of minerals and nuts. Rather smooth and light on the palate (for the style), well balanced and enjoyable.

A bit thin smell of sweet chocolate.
Nice thickness in the fluid. Balanced taste of sweet chocolate, coffee and nuts.

Bottle. Deep dark brown color. Malt, roast and dark chocolate in the aroma. Malty sweetish, roasty flavor with ash, cream, dark chocolate, tobacco. Almost full bodied, good complexity. Excellent brew.
From a bottle poured black with almost no head.  Strong toasted malty flavor with a lasting finish.

(bottle - 330 ml) Dark black pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet and very roasty at the beginning with a large amount of molasses and sweetly roasted malts. Lots of chocolate and roasted malt at the beginning with a mild roasty middle with hints of coffee and cocoa. Light bitter and surprisingly clean finish.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of toasted, molasses, dark chocolate and strong coffee, moderate resin for the hops and earth for the yeast. Head is average size, creamy/frothy with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is black. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy/syrupy and has a lively carbonation and a dry finish. The moderate hop profile balances well with the heavy malts in this Imperial Stout.

Pours black with nice brown head.  Aromel is of roasted malt and yeast.  Flavor is more balanced with notes of roasted coffee.  Palate is smooth with a slight hoppy bitterness on the end.  Enjoyable, but not great.  At 7% ABV, not really Imperial either.

33cl bottle. Dark ruby, nearly black, small mocca head. Strongly metallic aroma at start, Käck licorice, sweet molasses. Flavor has little acidic coffee beans, licorice drops, burned malts. Medium bodied, slightly bulky metallic palate. Luckily some of the off-putting metal fades when warmer. Utterly simple strong stout.

bottle, pours black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is nice with notes of carmel, milk, and roasted malt.  Solid chocolate and black malt body, thin notes of coffeeand spice.  Nice mellow roasty finish.

Compact tan head over a brown-black beer. Firm coffee aroma with elements of bananas, dark chocolate and a scruffy, woolly presence. Moderately sweet with an overall impression of dryness via roasted bitterness and coffeelike acidity. Slightly savory as well. Taste and aroma combine to make the flavor overwhelmingly of coffee. Medium-full bodied with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Quite unidirectional, though mostly pleasant in what it does. A moderate amount of fusel alcohols arrive as the beer warms. Simple, average. 33 cl bottle, bottled in September 2009.
33cl bottle, Alko. Pours black in color, thin brown head. Roasted malt aroma. Sweet flavor, liquirice and chocolate and coffee. Roasted bitter aftertaste. Delicious.

330 ml bottle. Pitch black, with a thin light brown head. Roasted malty aroma with dark chocolate, coffee and liquorice. The flavour is roasted, a little sweet at first, with chocolate, some dark fruits and spices. The finish is somewhat drier, roasted and bitter. Very tasty.

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a medium-sized tan head. The aroma of roasted malt with notes of liquorice and coffee. Sweetish and roasted with some bitterness and coffee. Medium-bodied, roasted and bitter aftertaste.

Black beer with a minimal beige head. The aroma has lots of dark malts, salty licorice and a hint of tar. Long lasting aftertast has sweetish dark chocolate, some roasted coffee and hops. Sweetish-chocolatey flavor dries up towards the finish ending a bit chalky and bitterish. Medium to full bodied palate, slick and a bit oily mouthfeel. Pretty tasty beer it is but not the most interesting.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2009 330ml bottle, unknown vintage but is likely several months old.  Aroma of dark chocolate, molasses, roasty malts, licorice, espresso, cream and faint prune.  Opaque ebony in color, head is a faint ring of light tan.  Flavor profile is unusual for the style but extremely well-balanced and refined, with aspects of dark, semi-sweet chocolate, latte and toffee, anise and other faint spices, showing hints of roasty bitterness towards the finish.  Largely dry, smooth mouthfeel, body is medium-full.  Not nearly as powerful or even as complex as some Imperials, but certainly nice in its own right.  More of a British or historical take on the style, seemingly.

Black beer with weak blond head. Aroma is strongly roasted, chalky and some coffee. Flavour is quite intensive, roasted, some liquirice and dry in the end. Nicely slippery to drink. Roasted, not-interested beer, there are better beers for this category.

It poured a pitch black liquid with a small light brown foam that left some lacing. It had an unexpected smell of fruit candy, black currant, blue berries and some sourness. It had a strong taste of burned toast, sweet chocolate, coffey and nuts. It was smooth and dry. A weird beer, the smell didnt match the taste at all, felt like two different beers.

11.2oz bottle matured about a year and a half poured at 55F.  Pours a clear deep dark red that is too dark to see though looking near black in the glass with a thin/medium bubbly tan froth 3.5.  Aroma is fruity like English ale yeast, matched by some light hard roast acidity, hint of soy sweet and saltiness, hint of dark chocolate, soft malt oxidation, smells very English 7.5.  Flavor follows, very bright and fruity with balanced roast, acidity, chocolate maltiness.  Some chewy tootsie-roll doughy quality as well , soft round and fruity.  The hard-roast coffee acidity is perfect without any of the tannic bitterness.  Wonderful very slight rich alcohol warmth in the finish.  Lingering grassy chocolate aftertaste with just a touch of coffee bitterness.  Medium/full bodied, round but dull in a good way, quite smooth and easy drinking, isnt at all heavy but still maintains a substantial mouth-feel, spread-out very fine popping carbonation 4.5.  With the amount of acidity this really reminds me of a traditional English porter, maybe a slight lactic infection.  Impressed, exceptionally drinkable and aged beautifully just when I was about to give up on aging imperial stouts... 
[I drank this bottle in like 15 minutes... I couldnt stop gulping, supremely drinkable... I LOVE the acidity!!!]

Got this bottle a few months ago at Sams in Chicago. I was worried that it might be turning as two other N O had. But, no problem here. Despite aggressive pouring only a small tan head that is mostly gone and no lace. Color is very close to opaque brown. Aroma is quite nice: malty, roasty, vanilla, cocoa, coffee, and leather. Flavor is about the same with a french roast finish and ultimately a hint of sweetness. Good body and carbonation. Tasty. A hint of alcohol  after some swallows. Could be a session beers despite its richness.

11.2 fl oz bottle purchased at Gomers in Lees Summit, Missouri. Pour is opaque black with only a small khaki head. Lacing is left behind on a swirl. Aroma of roast malt, soy and dark chocolate. The chocolate is more of the burnt variety than the sweet. Taste is sweet cane sugar, dark roast chocolate and a bit of the soy from the nose. Aftertaste has a weird mix of the soy and sweet.  As it warmed, became more pleasant.  Palate is thinner than expected, on the light side of medium. Decent amount of carbonation - really no hint of alcohol.  Decent enough.

Pours near black with ruby hues and a full receding tan head. Notes of bakers chocolates, rum, vanilla, red wine, fruit jam and caramel. Full bodied and winey with lively carbonation. A very elegant and delicious beer.

Bottle. Pours boring black with minimal head. Nose is dark roasted malt, molasses, black coffee, dark chocolate. Taste follows similar with bitter bite and watery mouthfeel.  Becomes almost slightly sour and very bitter, watery, but flavors are still good for and I.S. Not bad for a try.
Poured dark brown/black, coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, nutty, slight dark fruit.

Very nice.  Dark dark brown with tan head.  Hefty aroma of cocoa and baking chocolate and some dark fruit and raspberries.  Nice syrupy thickness to the palate, small bubbles, a tiny bit watery, nutty, neutral finish.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a Maudite snifter.
App.: Deep brown-black with a so-so might mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of rich, oily molasses, soy sauce, quite fruity, slightly vinous, some black licorice, dark chocolate, light esters of cotton candy, a hint of alcohol and of hops.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, moderate effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Fruity with some apples and other fruits, some molasses, a touch of brightness, some black coffee, some dark chocolate; fairly dry with some tartness and fairly good bitterness, leaves remnants of good dark chocolate.

Not huge but pretty good.

Pours very fine tight tan head. Dark black body, Aroma of fine chocolate crossed with molasses and coffee. Coca flavors in the taste. While there is some mouth feel, its pretty light, which doesnt surprise me for something thats only 7% alcohol. Nice beer over all.
Bottle. Black with a nice brown head. Aroma and flavour of coffee, roasted malt, spice, fruit, chocolate and caramel.
Draught @ Eskilstuna Ölkultur. Malty. Small smokeiness. Not bad, but nothing special.

12-JUN-2009.
Bottle at Ulkløbben.
Brown with an oily look, little beige/brown head.
Sweet chocolate and coffee. Malty but not very hoppy. Creamy, smooth, good.

Deep black pour with brown head. Aroma is of cocoa, chocolate, sweetness. Taste is of chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, sweetness. Leaves a dry mouthfeel. Some bitterness at the end. Leaves lacing on the glass. Alcohol is hidden. The roasted malt flavor lingers in my mouth.

Bottle @ Mondial de la Biere 2009 
Appearance:  quiet dark , dark brown , bit like coke at edges. Mid light creamy , beige look. 4-Nose:  good , thick roast , dark chocolate , bitterness of dark malts , espresso with shot of vodka. 7+Flavor/Palate : Superb roast qualities. Smoky ,roasty , toasted barley blend with mocha and tar. All ingredients and flavour elements well put together. Very smooth with soul of Baltic Porter in it. Delicious Old Europe.

Bu au Mondial 2009, le 4 juin (#11). Brunée torifiée, peu de collet. Arome de réglisse malté avec un peu dalcool. Goût de et de petits fruits, mocha malté avec une finission sec. Peut-être pas le bon style mais assé savoureuse!
Aroma is interesting, chocolates, roasted coffee.  Flavor does not uphold those notes, bland watery finish.  Not impressed.

Bottle.  Pours black with a small ring of tan head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malt, light roasted coffee, and sweet malt.  Flavor is sweet malt with off notes.  Vegetal notes abound.  Not a fan of this one...not sure what went wrong here.
7/4/6/3/12 (3.2/5)

Bottle. Aroma quite roasty with bitter chocolate, vanilla, and a few too many prunes and such. Flavor brings on some fairly weak coffee with roasted edges, again too many prunes. Its ok, no idea how fresh this is, though Id bet not fresh enough.

Very compact and clean package displaying hints of sour chocolate, nuts, and toffee, some dry fruits, brown shuggah, hint of smoke & lingering touch of hops. Blackish brown pour, brown highlights and tan head. Unexpectedly crisp, it slowly insinuates - the finish becomes rather long, the aroma fairly complete and it has a lot to offer with a very different classy Euro approach compared to the brazen west-coasties. Try one!!

Black color, (of course). Light brown head, wich is rather small. 
Aroma has notes of dark chocolate and coffe. 
Taste offers notes af dark Chocolate, coffe, roasted bread, and a little bit of smoked barley. it is a bit acidic. Body is medium. Carbonation is soft.
It is an quite ordinery stout, without eny surprises.

Black with a small disappearing brown head. Aroma: Roasted malt, liquorice, coffee, cocoa. some fruit too. Taste: very smooth. Cocoa, coffee, roasted malt, a hint of smoke, fruit, raisin, plum. Very good mouthfell. Great brew. I love this brewery.

Pours dark black, thin tan head.  Aroma is very malty and sweet, oats, some alcohol.  Taste is thick, meaty, almost gravy like in texture.  A sweetness of boiled sweets balances out the malty bitterness, also an odd taste a bit like iron filings.  Malty and bitter lingering finish.  Pretty damn good.

Tap @ The Rover. Black with a beige lasting head. The aroma is superb, plenty of cocoa, coffee, just hints of licorice. Its full bodied yet very drinkable, salty, balanced, with an almost endless lingering end.

Pours black with very creamy tan head.  Aroma of sweet dark fruits, toffee, and dark chocolate.  Flavor of sweet molasses, raisins, roasted coffee, and cocoa.  Minimal bitterness.  Medium bodiedfor trhe style with moderate carbonation.  Solid, it didnt blow me away.  (11.2 oz bottle)

Pours very dark brown with no head. 
Has a pleasant aroma of malt. plum, mollasses, and caramel. The flavor of this beer is amazing, I just cant get enough, its smooth, has good body and good carbination. With traces of coffee, roasted malts, semi sweet chocolate and brown suger.

11.2 Oz bottle purchased at Knightly Spirits in Orlado.  So I though
my nose was playing tricks on me.  I just had Mephistopheles and Oscar
smells very similar.  There is a big whole whallop of coffee in the
aroma, followed by some spice.  But the flavor on this one is so
delicate and fluffy.  It just goes down so smooth and ends with a very
good chocolate flavor.  SO how come this isnt labeled as a foreign
stout?

[1916-20081220] 11.2floz bottle. Burnt coffee ground roast aroma. Dark brown black body with a medium-lasting creamy tan head. Roasted grounds and heavy malt flavour has lots of burnt roasty fullness. Full body. Good and drinkable.
(w/ jerc)

Orlando, Fl. - Knightly Spirits - 11.2 oz bottle. Dark black pour with some purple tints - light khaki head that diminishes pretty quickly. Pleasant aroma of coffee, chocolate with hints of molasses. Good, solid stout flavor with plenty of bitter coffee notes, some bitter bakers unsweetened chocolate and just a hint of dates and raisins. Mouthfeel is clean and smooth. Very enjoyable and not overpowering.

Bottle. Black color, with a large brown head. The nose was sweet and malty, coffee and  a hint of smoke. Taste roasted malt, with coffee, roasted coffee(maybe a bid tobacco) with some dryed fruit short of hiding. Great aroma a bid disapointing taste for an imperial stout.

Thanks to akevitt for sharing.  Bottle, pours an almost opaque black body with red hues and a light brown head.  Aroma of hot chocolate, dark malts, and brown sugar.  Flavor of chocolate, burnt malts, sugar, licorice, and a hint of tar.  Medium bodied with a cocoa finish.  The mouthfeel is rather watery, although it gets less watery as it warms.

Thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: Pitch black, I shone a torch through it with no result. Huge tan head. Aroma: Coffee, cream, mint with slight peat notes and a tinge of orange peel. Flavour: Creamy & milky, mild, slight coffee/tobacco, a little malt, light on carbonation, nice creamy malt finish. I must agree with Harry, not an Imperial Stout...

Deep pitch black coloured body, completely opaque with a thin and fast dying tan head. Some brown transparency gets through on the side of the glass, but a bunch of bubbles rising from the sides are also noticeable - nice! Aroma of potent, deep, roasted malt, coffee, nuts and star anise. Some meaty and mushroomy scents also come out too - after the sweetness. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong assertive roasted malt up front fading to a complex meaty, spicey and nutty finish. Aftertaste is odd - effervescent then fading to a stillness, with more malt and coffee than anything else. Overall, this is an odd beer - Im all for the Foreign style instead of the Imperial, but it just doesnt work - its missing too much character, after the smell was so promising. Worth trying, I suppose - but Id rather have pretty much any other Foreign over this one! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Knightly Spirits in Orlando, Florida on 15-February-2009, sampled at home in Washington on 23-March-2009.
Bottle. Black and pored with a small head. Slightly malty with some chocolate flavors.Well balanced and smooth.

Bottle (330ml).  Courtesy of .... Reakt?.  * Rating # 3500 *   Looks like a stout - near opaque black with reddish edges, average frothy light tan lasting head.  Smells like a solid stout (not an impy) - dry roast coffee bean, leafy bitterness, cocoa, a little cream, mint, wisp of licorice - not much alcohol at all.  The taste is mild, lactic, bitter chocolate and acidic weak coffee, not much fruit but definite dry light herbal bitterness - very smooth and creamy, somewhat light bodied, mildly acidic and carbonated - quick malt finish, a little dry bitterness in the linger.  Pleasant, not world-beating - definitely not "imperial."
