Bottle: Pours black with an off white head. Aroma, fruits, some coffee, chocolate. Flavor, coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and a dry roasty bitterness. Good stuff.

Bottle. Big thanks to omhper for sending this all the way out here. Abv on this bottle is 7.0, not 6.5. Pours ruby-black, thin beige head with lacing. As I sit drinking this in the oppresive tropical heat of Taiwan, dreaming of a cool spring evening on the baltic as I sip this beer.

Thin tan head that faded quickly. Dark brown body. Faint aromas of chocolate and roast, lightly earthy with some medicinal notes. Body is light, thin, lightly creamy. Tasted 2007-03-18. Bottle from 2006, 33cl. Black with disappearing brown head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt and smoke. Taste of ditto. Its a good beer, but the smoke is a little too much for me!

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007 (Bottle) Pours dark to black with red hints. Roasted to smokey malt aroma with liquorice and dark, nutty bread. 2003 bottle. Thanks to Madsberg for this one. Refrigerated.
There is just a thin slice of tan head floating above this black oily brew.

On tap at delirium Café, Göteborg.
Dark, almost black with a small tan head.Lots of malt, coffee and chocolate tones. Medium to full body with a slightly dry finish.

Im a Nils Oscar fan, but this Impie doesnt push all the buttons for me. Looks great with a dark mahogany body under an attractive cinammon coloured head.

Dark beer with a thin brown head that left lots of lacing.  Brown sugar and coffee nose.  Molassess, licorice, roast coffee bean, with an almost celery leaf finish.  Nice, easy drinking Impy stout.  Thanks to my secret santa for the bottle.
Bottle. One of two readily available Swedish Imperial Stouts.. Rich and roasty, bitter.. but not hoppy. Sweet and rich liqourice and coffee. Good.. but maybe not outstanding.
Roast caramel apple and coffee aroma.  engine oil black with short tan head. delicious creamy milk chocolatey crisp apple coriander roast coffee bean. rather mild finish, modest gravity.

33cl bottle, best by May 2013 (maybe I jumped the gun on this - lol). Obtained in trade with my Secret Santa sunevdj - THANKS SUNE! Dark ruby with a thick, creamy, tan head. Bottle. Clear dark red color with a brown creamy head. Aroma of coffee, burned coffee beans and malt. Flavor is the same, coffee, dark chocolate. Medium finish.

Bottle from Plan B, Copenhagen. Dark and rich foir sure, but a little too sweet for me (for an Impy that is). Not the grainy, hardcore hoppy blackness that I hoped for. Still nice, but not the ultimate.
Bottle. Dark, with a lovely ruby tone. Easy drinking, but the quality is in the finish, with coffee, port, fruit and a warmth from the alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2008 Bottle: Dark red clear colour. With a brown creamy head.
Aroma of coffee,burned coffee beans,malty and have olso a slty nose in the end.
Flavor is almost the same,coffee,dark chocolate.Medium to full bodyand and a medium finish. Nice Nordic IMP Stout!.
Cask at Biskhopsarms Järn torget Göteborg. A moore smouth mouth feeling, than the bottle version, and  has a bigger body, then it is almost the same as the bottle version.8/58/4/12=4,0
[Bottle from System Bolaget] Aroma is roasted coffee, vinous, berry fruit, tar. Medium bodied, dry and sweet. Not really big enough.

Bottle. Thanks to jsquire for sharing this one. Small tan head that mostly diminished, lackluster lacing, no visible carbonation, opaque, and a black hue. Roasty, coffee, some chocolate notes and licorice. Flavor was roasty, coffee, malty, and chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel. Nicely done and worthy of a try IMO.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2006 (Bottle BB 05/13) Roasted malty, licorice and coffee aroma. Black (reddish) colour and small, brownish, more or less fully diminishing head with fair lacing. Burned/roasted malty, coffee, licorice, slightly bitter and sweet flavour. Dry, creamy, softly carbonated and medium to full-bodied palate with a hint of alcohol. Good imperial stout but not as tasty as Slottskällans respective one! 05/11/06 (original rating was 8/4/8/4/15)

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2006 RBESG 2006, bottle. Dark reddish brown colour, nearly black. Very nice roasty aroma, notes of bakery, coffee, liquorice and dark chocolate. Nice roasty flavour with rye bread and coffee notes, hints of chocolate. A very good stout.
Aroma is roasted and a bit vinous. Taste is similar balanced and quite good.

Pours an oily black with a thick light brown head. Big delicious aroma of coffee, molasses and plain roast barley. The palate is so full and thick, with plenty of coffee, molasses sweetness, helped along by perfect light carbonation. The roast barley flavour is spot on, slightly raw, but smoothed out by the definite presence of oatmeal. Outstanding.

thanks to heemer77  for sharing this rarity at a recent tasting.  great aroma of coffee with some licorice and raisins.  pour was very, very dark with a nice tan head.  a little different blend of flavors from what I have grown accustomed to, but this had a nice balance to it.  it all came together nicely and was very enjoyable!

Heemer77 shared this at a small tasting, thanks Eric.  Very dark pour with a mocha colored head.  Heavily roasted malts in the nose.  Dark chocolate and coffee flavors.  Slightly bitter finish. Good stuff

The last beer I recived in a trade with oh6gdx. This was also probably my favorite. This shows how a little subtlety can best in your face huge flavors. The black body was topped with a khaki colored head. The aroma was roasted coffee with a bit of chocolate and some brandy. The taste was lots of coffee with a little bit of brandy and some dark chcolate. There was also a nice roasted character in the background. Smooth and well balanced, this is a winner.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2007 Tasted at Vinens Verden... Brown edge, very little head. Roasted, caramel, and rye. Hints of almost burned malt.
Nice Imperial stout.

Holy shit! Aroma: like warm chocolate, some coffee. Wow! The beer is black with quite dark foam. The taste is simply... wow! What is there to say? A great beer. I will not try to describe this one, sorry guys.
Bottle. Black. Aroma of raisins and dessert wine. Roasted and bitter aroma, coffee. Medium long finish

This bottled brew that came compliments of Jeff Squire poured  a dark brown colored foamy head of finely sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a fair lacing on top of an opaque dark brown colored body that was ruby red brown around the edges with no visible carbonation.  The aroma was vinous with dark brown malts and mild roasted malts in the nose.  The mouth feel was mildly tingly at the start and medium in the finish.  The flavor was of dark brown malts and mild roasted coffee.

Friends of ours brought a bottle of this and the barleywine back from a recent trip.  To me, this was a very small imperial stout - maybe Im too americanized.  Medium body, medium hoppiness.  Some roasted flavors, but also some grass or hay.  More porter like to me.

Bottled. Black in colour. Foamy and rich brown head, lacings. The aroma has a strong influence of burnt malt. The flavour is sweet mixed with a sensation of burnt malt and some coffee. There is a sweet aftertaste as well.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2007 (Blind rating at sk8vikings.) Pours black with a light brown head. Sweet with  aromas of toasted malts and a hint of vanilla. Aslo hints/burbs of sweet liquirish. Low carbonation. Medium bodied. Dry sweet finish.

(Bottle 33 cl) Black and opaque with a lightly creamy, beige head. Nose of roasted malt and coffee. Medium body with lightly burned coffee notes - rather distinct coffee actually. Lightly bitter finish from the malts. 020606

Bottle. Pours a deep brown body with red tinges on the edges and a small white head. The aroma has raisins, yeast, and chocolate. The flavour isn’t as smooth as I’d like it to be with simple notes of caramel, chocolate, and toffee. Pretty good but not spectacular.
Sampled at the Københavnske Øldage 2006 on May 20, 2006.

Aroma has sharp salty soy notes, esspresso, dark chocolate, roasted notes and delicious fudge brownie kind of smell. Dark brown to black body with a quickly diminishing wispy mocha head. Very sharp and bitter in the fore, but it is a burnt bitter not a hoppy bitter. Lots of dark chocolate flavors that are both sweet and bitter. Its pretty thin on the palate, but the incredible intensity of flavor moderates that a little.  Feels like a porter int he mouth, but there are no mistaking the soy, coffee, chocolate and immensely bitter burnt flavors of an IS.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2008 Sort øl (33 cl) købt i Sverige og Kvickly

A very tasty stout. Lots of malt and hops in the taste. Since I had it right out of a bottle I cant really judge the aroma too well. Some tastes of chocolate as well. Will review this as soon as I have from a glas. I expect it to be soon.

Black body, brown shine, light brown creamy fast disappearing head, some laces; Very intense nose, not very deep, but quite complex: sweet soy sauce (not salty), bitter chocolate, milk chocolate, toffee; balanced body, with great carbonation and a soft texture; into long but a bit thin finish, quite bitter with licorice, bitter chocolate, some malt, some alcohol. the alcohol shines through in both nose, body and finish, but all in all very, very nice beer, that I wish I had some more bottles of.

2003 Vinatge:  Poured a very dark brown color with a copper rim and small tan head.  Tan oily film on the glass walls.  Nice aroma of chocolate, smoke, and light soy.  Sweet and roasty malt.  Dark fruits and light alcohol.  Roasted malt flavor.  The flavor was light though.  Maybe from the age.  Roasty bitter finish.  Body is a little thin for an IS.
Bottle. Pours in a glass this black beer with its light browninsh foam. Looks very good. And the taste! Haevy, roasty, medium sweetness and a long finnish. One of the better stouts.

Bottle into tulip glass, The Friday imperial stout tasting, summer 2005.  Almost dope.  Head disipates quickly.  Transluscent ruby in the glass.  Tan head.  Smooth and medium bodied.  Flavor starts woody with port, transitions to full chocolate and a good level of malt sweetness, and then a dry roasty and bitter finish with a hint of alcohol showing through.  By the books, exactly what I like in an imperial stout.  I wish it were a bit fuller in the body, though.

Thanks to mrwalker for the trade...
Aroma:chocolate,dark cocoa...
Appearance:dark,good tan head..
Flavor:Dark chocolate,cocoa.Light expresso flavor...

12 oz bottle, via MrWalker.  Oily black body with a thin covering of light brown head.  No sediment in bottle.  Dense roasty nose with milk chocolate, coffee, anise, and some alcohol.  Flavor is balanced between burnt malt and dark cocoa.  Nice bitter and espresso finish, very well rounded flavor profile.  Texture is oily but not thick at all.  Very smooth with pleasant carbonation, despite not being bottle conditioned.  A very good Imperial Stout.  This would be great if kept alive and non-filtered, it loses some of the softness and fullness in the mouthfeel that could have been there potentially.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Black with a light brown head. Chocolate and dried fruit aroma. Rich, burned and bitter flavour with only little chocolate sweetness. Dry, roast malt aftertaste. 
One year old bottle: Nothing to add, really. Still awesome.

Almost black with quickly disappearing light brown head. Delicious bitter chocolate aroma. Roasted flavours, bitter chocolate, good bitterness underneath. Full body. Delicious beer for a special moment, it would age well also.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2007 Bottled. Dark brown to black colour, thick brown head. Very roasted nose, sweetish with black coffe. Espresso with lots of sugar.  Taste is roasted, deep, with chocolate, black coffee and black rye bread, some dried fruit and liquorice as well. Stunning stuff! Rerate: (draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, 26 Feb 2007, vintage unknown, but probably not very young) Black colour with brief, brown head. Roasted nose with chocolate, some smoke, tobacco, liquorice and hints of tar. Roasted taste with chocolate (a bit like Ben & Jerrys chocolate ice-cream with chocolate chunks), cocoa and notes of coffeeish bitterness. Medium to full body, smooth as velvet and in fantastic balance.

33 cl bottle, 7% ABV, BB January 2011.  Thanks to the sk8viking!  Poured damn-near black (only some faint mahogany sparkle under the beer light)... capped with a light ring and pool of cappuccino head.  Even with my cold, I picked up a full array of roasty dark malts... coffee and fresh licorice at the forefront, with dark chocolate and raisins not far behind. Bottle. Umm - very very nice - a bit of coffee and raisins and handsome head. Good and creamy feel. Also malty and a bit of bitter chocolate. A really really good stout.

330 cL bottle thanks to my friend juha in finland.  aroma of burnt oatmeal, coffee, raisins, smoke, chocolate - imagine anything dark that might possibly go into a beer and the aroma has it.  smooth licorice and bitter unsweetened chocolate, with a warm malt throughout.    medium finish, with an evaporative finish tasting like bitter coffee.  if it were "fuller" this would be top-notch, but its excellent as it is.  thanks juha!

Brown, creamy head with larger bubbles. Black opaque body, possibly slightly brown at the edges. Faint aroma of chocolate and coffee. Sweet, firm taste with smoky notes, rather soft round the edges. Somewhat mild for an imperial stout, even a little watery. No real aftertaste, just dries up. Coffee notes linger. A good imperial stout, but not among the best.

Nice liquorice and coffee aroma, but not overly powerful. Black but not pitch black, nice lacings but light-brown head with low staying-power. Fairly light body for an Imperial Stout. Taste is fine with coffee, chocolate and liquorice notes. Finishes with long roasted aftertaste combined with a nice bitterness.

33 cl.
Brown/Black colour. 
Creamy brown head. Roasted coffee aroma. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. Coffee flavour. sweet, chocolate.

(33cl bottle, 7% ABV, best by 1/2011?) Medium tan head atop a black body.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is medium sweet, milk chocolate, smoke, some roast, light raisin, coffee.  Taste is medium sweet, chocolate, some raisin, caramel, light coffee.  Finishes solidly roasty and lightly smoked.  Creamy medium body.  Much thinner than an American Impy Stout, but delicious in its own way.

33 cl bottle. Black colour with a fantastic creamy head. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee and roasted barley. Very smooth aroma. Great flavour of smooth complexity blend with roasted barley. Overall a wonderful and great stout. I have made blindtestes with this and many others imperiel stout several times, conclusion :This is diffently one of the best.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2006 Draught, at Bishop Arms.
More smooth.
Bottle, at No. 5.
Dark brown with brown head, amostly disappearing, no lacings. Aroma heavy malty (licorce, dark fruit) and light hoppy. Flavor light sweet, moderate bitter, long duration. Medium body, oily, flat carbonated. 6-2-7-4-14/3,3.

Bottled.  7.0% ABV Brownish thick black. Small brown head. Coffeish, caramelly roastmalty aroma with notes of dried fruits. Roastmalty, bitterchocolatey taste with a medicine-bitter, peppery finish. Hints of smoke and liquorice. Not quite fullbodied, rather a bit thin for the style. Although this is a perfectly fine example of the style, I notice that my initial love affair with this style has faded and that the Stone Imperial Stout, which I loved, is rather an exception to the norm. Bottle, courtesy of MrWalker. Thanks!

33 cl bottle. Nice tan head. Aroma is complex and dominated by licorice - like those soft Finnish licorices. Flavor is extremely balanced with sugary sweetness leading to more licorice. Watery mouth feel. Finishes with some warming alcohol, which is surprising, considering the low ABV.

Very, very black liquid. Some candy sweetness and alcohol in the aroma, lots of malty grain and a slight trace of espresso. Not much is going on in the flavour department aside from a gentle chocolatey sweetness. A light-hitting, drinkable stout.

Tonight I toast Ompher. You assuredly have a place in Valhalla! (In other words, thanks for this great brew!)
Opaque, tar colored with a small tan head (nice lacing too). Fudge bubblegum aroma, a chocolate milkshake more juiced than Jose Canseco. A creamy Cappuccino front with a spicy black peppercorn middle, a sweet cocoa finish and to cover the bases, a slightly bitter finish. Like an E- ticket ride at Disneyland, this beer takes you through all sorts of twists and turns!
Im admittedly rather a novice with Impy Stouts but this is a style I have come to love!

Nearly black with a light brown creamy head. Nice espresso aroma with dark chocolade and honeydew melon marmelade. Heavy taste of chocolade in the begining fading to coffe and charamel. This is a beer perfect to the evening in front of the fireplace in combination with chocolade or cheese.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 Bottle. Black colour. Small, dark brown head. Roasted coffee aroma. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. Coffee flavour. Semi-sweet, a little chocolate. 7 4 8 4 17

2003 bottle, 4 years old, 7.0%. Creamy aroma with a little liquorice. Black colour, small light brown head. The flavour is good, quite distinct liquorice, ending with a little salty sweetness. There is also a little paper, but nothing unpleasant. The aftertaste is very late and has some fresh-ground coffee and a little barley bitterness as well as a little more paper. Good mouthfeel and pleasant carbonation. I think it has peaked for me at 4 years. 7 4 8 4 16

Bottled.
Dark brown coloured with a lacing beige head.
Aroma of smoke, chocolate and coffee.
Roasted flavour of coffee, chocolate and smoke with a dry hoppy finish.

Black colour. Thick beige creamy head.
Dark chocolate nose. Roasted flavour with coffee notes and hints of plum . Bitter hoppy palate.
Somewhat alcoholic, but still an excellent stout.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 Bottled. Black opaque with big creamy brown head. Malty aroma with smooth roasted notes as well as a bit fo coffee. Flavour of plum and roasted malt. Hints of licorace in aftertaste. Sticky mouthfeel. 7 4 8 3 14
Bottled. Black opaque with big creamy brown head. Malty aroma with smooth roasted and coffee. Also some slight vanilla and fruits. Flavour of plum, roasted malts, coffee, wood, vanilla and some slight hints of toffee and caramel. Hints of licorace in aftertaste. Very wellbalanced. 8 5 8 4 17.
Black, tall beige head. Chocolate aroma. Coffee. Roasted malt. Rich flavour dominated by coffee, chocolate, roasted malts. Smoke? Dry finish. Smooth palate. A masterpiece.

Bottle.  Pours a deep black color.  Tan head fades out to ring the edge of the glass.  Little lacing left behind.  Aroma is rich with chocolate and raisin notes.  Body is medium.  Lighter than the US Imperial Stouts.  Richly flavored with Deeply roasted malts.  Quite tasty!!!  Thanks to Jeppe!!!!
Dark colour. Lmoust black. Off-white head. Great roasted malt aroma! Chocolate in nose. Sweet taste to beagin and finishes bitter. Best stout I´ve had so far.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2005 Black! Intensive taste of what feels like dark roasted coffee. Lots of malt and hops. The after-taste is a little bitter and leaves you with a smile on your face. Highly recommended!

Impressively thick black body with enjoyable brownish head. Incredible roast presence with coffee, chocolate and perhaps tobacco. Good long lasting romantic finish with bitter-smoke effect. Thanks Eructoblaster for this very enjoyable product!

Bottle. Right up there with the best impy stouts Ive had. Aroma is slightly bittersweet chocolate with some dried fruits, all very subtle but noticeable. All of the flavors meld perfectly along with some tobacco.
Tasted the 2003 brew. Light brown creamy head on a devy dak brown body. Chocolate-coffee notes in the taste, which is strong an stout. Good for long cigar evening. Perfect for long Winter nights.

Nearly black with a light brown creamy head. Nice espresso aroma with dark chocolade and honeydew melon marmelade. Heavy taste of chocolade in the begining fading to coffe and charamel. This is a beer perfect to the evening in front of the fireplace in combination with chocolade or cheese.

Rating #1600!, bottle via my Secret Santa (aka Mads): Nearly opaque with fading head but produced a nice oily ring which clings to the glassware. The aroma has notes of burnt and caramelized malting, espresso, bittersweet mocha, raisin, aromatic hops, tobacco, and moderate phenols. The taste starts silky smooth with lots of chocolate overtones followed by a rush of coffee and burnt characteristics. Light fruity nature show up to add depth.  Good use of lingering bitters upon the finish. While the feel isnt huge, it works well and gives a crisp to smooth transition with just a bit of saltyness and chalkyness. This is a well done stout in the classic vain. Easily drinkable on a cold winter eve.

Opaque black body topped with a diminishing light brown creamy head. Nice roasted coffee aroma with dark chocolate and toffee hints. Taste is delightfully complex. Texture is mild, and alcohol is well hidden. Flavors of malt, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and brown sugar. Strong and long smokey/hoppy finish. Definitely the best from Nils Oscar.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2007 (Rerate, 18.12.2004, 9-4-8-5-16) Near black colored, little dark brown head. Aroma is sweet with strong roasted chocolate and licorice, oak and vanilla come up too, very rich and strong aroma. Medium to full bodied. Strongly roasted flavor with dry and lasting roasted aftertaste. Vanilla, chocolate and oak also strongly there, nice balance in flavor. Chocolate comes up also in the lasting aftertaste with convenient hops. Nicely mild carbonation fits here well. Amazing aroma here!
Dark brown body with beige head. Aroma has some roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Flavor starts of sweet, but ends with a bitter chocolate touch. Palate is a bit thin. Beer No. 400!

Sampled with omhper, tiggmtl, MartinT, muzzlehatch, and Rastacouere in Montreal.  Thanks to Per for this bottle.  Chocolate aroma with hints of coffee and your typical maltiness.  early opaque dark brown with a light tan head.  Sweet to start with chocolate notes to finish.  Quite roasty, but somewhat thin.

Malty, sweet aroma with notes of licorice apparent. Opaque dark brown with thin white fully-diminishing head. Roasty and sweet. Enjoyable if simple. Medium body. A really solid enjoyable beer. Bottle enjoyed with DYCSoccer17, MartinT, muzzlehatch, Omhper and Rastacouere.

omhper in Montreal #27 (with MartinT,tiggmtl,Rastacouere,DYCSoccer).  Black, slightly less than opaque with a lasting bit of foam...chocolate and a hint of whiskey and no real alcohol in the nose...licorice appears late, and stays in the medium-sweet, roasty body...solid example of the style without being quite spectacular.  Thanks so much Per!

Deep brown hue, light off-white ring. This impy comes out with a joyous fruit salad aroma to top the chocomalt with typical roasted coffee, well-hidden alcohol and more interesting oat chunks flavors, but its less salivating than a perfectly balanced slottskallans from my point of view. Truffles on the tongue, smooth and quite light for the style. Good roastiness. Interesting flour character, but less pleasant off-dryness, not chalky, but somehow ashes-like dusty. Medium body, low carbonation. Above average imperial stout. Cheers Per!

Roasty fruitiness meets black molasses in a surprisingly full malt body for the brewery...Fine carbonation lets plenty of room for the chocolate and lingering roasty bitterness...My favorite of theirs so far, yet I would take Slottskällans over this one anytime...Thanks Per!!...

2003... Poured a very dark brown color with a tan head that quickly dissipated, leaving no lacing on the glass.   Aroma of fudge, chocolate, roast, star anise, and cognac.  Sweet, roasty, chocolate taste up front, with a dry, earthy, lightly bitter hop finish.  Smokey with light alcohol notes.  Thanks Mads!

The colour is opaque black, the medium-thick foam deep brown. 

The smell is dominated by a dry, bitter flavour with lots of black coffee. 

The taste is bittersweet with a burned tone; some coffee, some cocoa. The aftertaste is long and rich, full of fine bitter hops.

Bottled at BBB gathering post GBBF 2004. Extremely dark colour - almost black. Very rich. Fruity and on the sweet side, with coffee, licorice and some hop character too. Only let down very slightly by a somewhat oily mouthfeel. I was pretty far gone by this time, but I was compos mentis enough to know a good beer. Bottled at BBB gathering post GBBF 2004.

2003: Low carbonation, oily appearance, no legs though. The aroma is lightly roasty and chocolatey with a rather thin overall persona. The flavor is very balanced with a touch roasty chocolate and mocha espresso notes. Finishes thin for an imperial stout but Im not letting that get to me, its still delicious.

(2003) Black tan head that quickly leaves. No lace. Roast and coffee malts. Chocolate and some raisins. Bitter hops. Flavor is a touch smokey. The raisins are there again. Chocolate comes out. Bitter hops. Almost sour. Palate is really cloying and lingering. The body is thick. Finishes roasty with bitter alcohol.

Bottle of the 2001 vintage (7%).  Thanks to omhper for the trade.  Dark brown to black color with a laced brown head. Intensly rich chocolate aroma with ginger and raisins in the nose.  As it warms the port-like qualities come through well in the aroma.  Somewhat more understated in the flavor with chocolate and some smoked malts.  Quite nice.

Bottled, vintage 2002 (BB 02/2008)
Opaque black, small tanned head. Roasted, malty, almost wineous aroma. Chocolaty, roasted, light but an excellent balanced palate. Carbonated, a bit sweet in finish.
Black color, llight iquorice coffee aroma and taste, full body, bitter sweet finish.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2008 Sweet, Twizzlers, malty and chocolatey, coffee. Black with foamy tan head. Thick body with light-medium carbonation. Chocolate-coffee start, molasses. Malty finish, dark and rich. After is medium bitter with coffee roasted bitterness.
2008/03/19: From bottle; Dusty and sweet, with molasses, smoke, coffee, and roasted-toasted grains. Light sour metallic twinge, but rich and malty. Deep dense black liquid, with thin light tan lacing head. Thick oily body with medium carbonation. Starts rich with roasted grains, molasses and smoke, dark chocolate, and plums. Dry roasted bitter finish with sweet rich ending. Good as I remember it. No change in numbers.

Coffee, brown sugar or sirup aroma.
Jet black, low creamy brown head.
Brown sugar tastenotes, mellow roasted notes. hops noticable on the back edge.
Coffee retronasal - toffee aftertaste.
Creamy mouthfeel.
Bottled meal. Very nuanced aromas. Nice smooth flavor. A little to sparkly mouthfell, but overall a great stout.

Bottle, DBF 2004. Deep red black, thin beige head and moderate condition. Gentle coffee and roast barley aromas, good sweet malt, liquorice and coffee in the mouth and a nicely judged blend of coffee bitterness and chocolate sweetness in the finish.

BB June 2008.  Thick, powerful garnet body with a fluffy, tan head.  Sweet, grainy malt aroma with chocolate, caramel, toasted grains, nuts and loaves of freshly baked bread.  There isnt much vinous character or even alcohol in the nose, but Im not too disappointed.  The body is smooth and very creamy, but not as big or rounded as one would like.  The flavors are enjoyable, but rather indicative of the aroma.  Nothing is big and overbearing as some Imperials are, but whats here is tasty and well balanced.  The problem is that some key elements are missing.  Being not as sweet in the malt, lacking the strong hops and without the vinous fruity character I cant help but feel a little let down.  Many thanks to Jeppe for sending this all the way from Denmark.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2005 Keg (2003) @ Ardbeg Room, StockholmThick lovely head. Caramel, vineous, burned, dusty, coffee, chocollate, dark fruits, sweet, salt,  yes a complex beer but not overwhhelming. Balanced for the style. Id like to try this vintage again in five years time.
Deep brown color with no head. The taste is burned malts with light coffee notes and light chocolate finish.

2003 Bottle. No head. Color is dark, dark, dark. Astringent alcoholic aroma, with a little coffee. Medium bodied. Taste is roasted malt and alcohol up front, big burnt coffee finish that sits in your mouth for awhile. A very good stout, just not exactly what this stout lover is looking for. For 7%, alc should be more masked.

Dark walnut with rusty edges. Very light. Persistently creamy tan ring. Meaty, roasty aroma with plenty of licorce and dark grapes. Subdued dried plum and caramel couple with substantial smoke and dark chocolate. Masked airiness flirts with the subtle charred malts and tar. Firm body. Minimal, soft carbonation. Earthy yeast backbone is swiftly quelled by the lightly acidic black malts and excessive roastiness. Wax and tingly licorice remain in the background. Finishes softly, filmy, and fairly vinous, yet with a sharp, lightly acrid black malt edge, which enriches the roastiness. Hints of leathery malts, cotton, caramel, and toast. Roasted barley, smoke, and black malts linger underneath the earthy, buttery yeast. Well-integrated roasted and charred malts, but rather simplistic. Overall,  the intense roastiness all-too abruptly shortens the finish and  pretty much overwhelms the mocha, caramel, rich malts, dark fruits, etc., which I happen to seek in this style. Solid and interesting, but its missing body and heft, in particular.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Nice bottle. Nice almost black with a hint of ruby body, with a medium fizzy tan head. Lots of tiny bubbles on the inside of the glass. Aroma is licorice, coffee, milk chocolate and a hint of soy. The flavor is incredible, dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts and a nice bitterness in the end. Very full-bodied and a true mouth filler. The best thing to come out of sweden since snuff tobaco.
Black colour. Small head. Malty, roasted, liqourice, coffee-bitterness, low carbonation, silky palate. Nice but forgettable.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2006 Bottle... This beer rocks! ... Very dark ale with ruby highlights. Small, fizzy, well-tanned head with an orange tint.
The nose is of milk chocolate and macadamia nuts with lesser notes of shoe polish and Jamaican coffee.
Well-rounded flavor with notes of chocolate, vanilla and  dark coffee.
Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Lengthy, dry, astringent finish. World class brew! Thanks bierkonig!

2001 Vintage: Opaque dark brown color with a medium beige head. Strong sweet cherry, chocolate, caramel and bread aroma. Roasty dark fruit, caramel and chocolate flavors with a strong salt aftertaste. Flavor is strong at first, but quickly disappears. Light carbonation, soft feel with a wet finish.

Sampled from 50 deg to 60 deg F.2001 Vintage - 7% ABV: Very dark brown, opaque, with a medium-sized tan head. The aroma was of dark chocolate, cherries, licorice, with a distinct salty tone. The flavor was of very sweet chocolate, licorice, and a nice salty aftertaste. The feel was very soft, thick, creamy, wet finish. Thanks so much for this surprise John!

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2006 (Bottled, 7.0% ABV) Almost black color with a small, brown head. Chocolatey aroma with spices (orange-peel, coriander), sweet malt and smoky licorice hints. Sweetish flavor of chocolate, licorice and lots of strongly roasted malt, plus a very bitter, long finish. ABV is well hidden. Slicky-smooth, medium to full-bodied palate with low carbonation. A very enjoyable, slicky-roasty imperial stout. A bit on the light side for an Impy, but definitely not bad, considering the low ABV.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2004 What a beautiful beer!! Nice medium creamy dark beige head on a almost totally black body (if you look closely it has a reddish glow!)!! Quite spicy nose of roasted malt, English ligourice and sweet chocolate. Smooth body with flavors of coffee, dark chocolate, liquorice and malt. Sweet at first but turns bitter after a while! Very nice balanced and a very good and smooth stout. My best so far......

(2003) Slim dirty brown head, on top of a beer that for all the world looks like Coca-Cola. Dark chocolate and forest fruits in the nose, Sachertorte. Very restrained bitterness for this - still lots of hops (specially retronasal) and roasted/burnt malts. Massive gravity, yielding lots of sweetness. Chocolate still much in evidence, some fruit. Full bodied, yet palate is not overpowering. Aftertaste gets more coffeeish and cigarette ash. Again, this starts out superbly, just to end a bit light. After all, 7% is not much for an Imperial Stout. I still remain a WWS 18%...

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2004 Very dark, almost black with a nice and creamy brownish head. Has a fresh and sweet aroma from chocolate. Flavor is a little smoked, sweet and bitter, from cocoa and chocolate. Nice palate and a rather discreet finish.

2003 7.0%ABV. This pours jet black with virtually no head. The body is medium, with a definite smoothness on the palate. The flavors are slightly chocolatey, with some roasted notes and a touch of bitterness. Very nice

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2006 2003 vintage: Pours a nearly opaque dark brown with a thin-lacing tan head.  Aroma of biscuity, lightly oxidized malt with a hint of tartness.  Body has a nice, lightly sweet and complex flavor that is very drinkable.  This has aged pretty well.

2002 7.0% abv: Pours a thick creamy opaque black with a nice thick tan head.  Sweet gingerbread, caramel, toffee, cinnamon, milk chocolate and graham cracker aroma.  Very smooth, somewhat oily body has a pleasant balance of sweetness and malty complexity.  Light roasted coffee finish.  So enjoyable all around, this imperial stout is a masterpiece.  Thank you raindog for sharing this rare gem!

2002:Black/dark mahogany shades. Medium,tan head leaves decent ring. Complex,malty aroma. Chocolate,coffee(with cream),toffee,dark fruit,little roast&alcohol. Oily,creamy mouthfeel. Velvety texture,big body. Malty,fruity,coffee flavors. Finish is long and lasting. Excellent,fruity and chocolate notes.Lightly burnt,with smoke/wood. As it loses a bit of carbonation,the palate improves from a 4to5. Extremely soft without any watery qualities. Chewy lingering flavors. Yummy!

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 (2001 verson) Black in colour, thick, small brownish head. Aroma of raisin, dark chocolate and coffee (maybe some black olives?). Taste:Smooth and malty with hints of tobacco and espresso. Aftertaste: very longlasting taste of espresso, dried plums, dark unsweet chocolate with smoky notes. A great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2004 Very dark.
Quiet fruity with smoke in the aroma.
A very pronounced flavour with a lot of smoke and tar; porter-ish.

Mmmmm...jesus christ! I usually say that beer should not taste like candy BUT this is a golden moment. Like a child, I pour this black wonder in the glass, feel the somewhat licoriceswet aroma and then let it run down the palate and oh so beautiful it is. As you read this, I am still enjoying the bitter, oh so wonderful bitter aftertaste.
A black beer with a beutiful light brown head. The aroma is slightly fruity, smoked, and sweet. The flavor is very sweet, smoked, and fruity. It has a fantastic palate. A really good beer.
Amazingly hit and miss. Blackest of black color. Head was non existent. Nose was "inky-thin". This mouthfeel- especially for the style. Good layers though in the flavors.
Dark brown, maybe amber coloured beer with a medium disappearing brown slightly creamy head. Roasted malty aroma and taste. Vinous character. A bit dry roasted aftertaste. A really nice beer.
Another fine Imperial!  Fruity, malty aroma.  Taste of cherries and chocolate.  Sweet finish.  Thanks Per
dark ruby with dark cherries aroma; raisin chocolatey taste; very sweet aftertaste; delicious.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 15, 2003 2001 bottle: Is dark almost black coloured. Has a huge lightbrown head that last long. Very roasted in the aroma. Notes of expresso and sweet chocolate and fruit (raisin?). Very flavourful. Heavyly roasted with sweet alcahol notes. Smooth and complex. Pleasantly bitter in the aftertaste. This is a goddamned good beer.
Bottle courtsey of Omhper, wonderfull full aroma, delightful red tiny, good lace, smooth flavor with great hop finish, maybe a little over balanced, but it works out well.
A more mild Imperial, I think.  Give this time to warm up and it releases a series of strong ale and roasted/malty flavors, though certainly not imbalanced or overpowering.  Very nice.  Thanks Per!

Bottle, courtsey of Omhper.  Dark-amber, not quite as dark as other imperial stouts.  NICE aroma: "dark cherries" is the phrase that comes to mind.  It follows through quite well in the flavor.  The mouthfeel was a bit too thin but otherwise it was a great example of the style.  Per rules!
Dark brown in color with a thin beige head.  Lots of carbonation in this stout, very full with typical imp stout qualities but distinguished by a nice spiciness on the tongue.  Nice!
Black firm body with no lace. Taste of chocolate, coffee, raisins, nutmeg. Excellent!

Pitch black pour with a fading tan head.Nose is full of dark chocolate,molasses.Thick full mouthfeel a little oily,coating my mouth with wonderful flavors of ripe plums and raisins.I like the fact that this brew is very full bodied but manages not to be heavy. Could drink a lot of these. Thanks hopsrus!

Nice aroma - bitter chocolate, roasted coffee - but light. Opaque with hints of red - little layer of a head. Fruity, roasted coffee beans - light hoppy undertones. Pricks slightly on the tongue. Long lasting fullmouth aftertaste. Nice and suprisingly very refreshing. Thanks so much Per!

After getting a whiff of the initial aroma, I stuck my nose further in the glass and just kept it there for a few minutes sucking up the wonderful aroma. Very intense nose of coffee, dark fruits (raisins) and toast, laced with alcohol. Opaque brown-black color and a low, tight, lacy head. Strong dark roasted malt taste with hints of tobacco. Esspresso in the middle. Sweet, sugary end on the lips after the swallo. Thick-ish. Aggressive and powerful. Not sure of the overall balance, but who cares? Pretty freaking good! Thanks ompher.
Pure stout taste and aroma. Has a bit of sweetness and a bit more bitternes. The sweetness is realy fine.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2009 2009-02-11, draught at Glenfiddich Warehouse N. 68, Stockholm, 7% ABV, 8-5-8-4-17=42Black color, creamy head. Mild coffeish aroma, a bit milky; later, light cheesy touch too; eventually, light Fernet Branca (Italian digestive). It has a medium body strength, with the mouthfeel getting rounder after the beginning; excellent flavor that happily marries chocolate caramel and roasted malt; balanced bitterness, and behind the dark malts maybe a good hop hides; milky feeling. Perfectly mature. Excellent.2002-11-29, bottle, vintage 2001, 6.5% ABV, 9-5-8-5-17=44Black color, brown cap.Big aroma, of roasted malt, liquorice, coffee, chocolate.Good body structure, rather dry; roasted malt, a lot of liquorice, coffee malt; unfortunately its still a bit metallic, possibly would improve with age. Heavy bitterness, augmented by the roasted/burnt bitterness, as well.Very good example, extra bitter stout, hiding well the alcohol content.

Fairly thin head over a typical imperial body.  Hints of cherry in the nose.  Very sweet with a satisfyingly roasty finish, it has a mild chocolate influence throughout.  As it warms, the alcohol becomes more pronounced, which is odd considering its strength. Overall, a right tasty brew.
Black color, small tan head, taste of chocolate and coffee,nice burnt bitterness.

Imperial Stout Blind Tasting (11-16-02): Little to no head on a dark body. Huge aroma: chocolate, cherry fruitiness, slight alcohol. The flavor has a thin bitterness, not sure whether its bittering hops or just the burnt malt. The dry slightly burnt flavor is unexpectedly meak after the big bold aroma. Slight woodiness in the flavor.

RateBeer Summer (Toronto) 02: 2000 Bottle, pours black, wine/plum nose with a bit of chocolate.  Full bodied, starts off sweet and ends crisp.  Bitter aftertaste goes on forever.  Well maybe a bit longer than that.
Full bodied. Well roasted. Some sweetness. LOOOONG aftertaste.
A really great Imp.stout,with lots of roasted malt and coffee in the taste .Great body and just a little sweetness

I had the 2001 version with 7.0% alc. Nice creamy chocolate head. Lots of coffee and raisins in the nose. The flavour is smoother and milder than the Danish Imperial Stouts, which I usually drink. The finish is bitter and coffeeish. A great brew.
Regulary, better than other ISs!
Had the 2001 version, which is 7% by the way. Not very strong aroma, roasted, coffee, chocolate. Very black, brown frothy head, good lacing. Full, sweet, roasted. Long finish, very roasted, coffee.
A great Imperial Stout, Black in colour, sweet smelling however, the sweetness didnt shine through in the taste, very nice roasty coffee flavour, with a nice bitter finish, very nice.

Black in color, chocolate head that dissipates quickly, nice lace. Nose is roasty and toasty, coffeeish, malt laden. Start is sweet, the top medium, the finish is moderately carbonated, acidic, dry and has a nice touch of hops. Some how, these flavorful dark beers dont seem as a logical choice for people in Sweden? I mean that in the kindest way, as they have so many nice looking Blond Beers, that I cant seem to find, although I continually Bash Lagers/Pils I think there must be something Im missing?.Thanks Per
Nice smokey scent. Dark brown. Tastes of chocolate and good chocolate at that. Rich, complex, slight trace of oils reminding again du chocolat. Excellent, Thanks Per.

Hmmm...tiny, lazy bubbles making up a nice tan head, well retained. Dark, but not super impenetrable. Nice aroma wafts in...a hefty smokiness, some dark fruitiness. Reminiscent of a sharp porter, but with slight wineyness, fruitiness, and real depth. But not as full-bodied as most imperial stouts, in my limited experience. Very very good. I like the balance in this beer. Sweetness increases substantially as it warms, but doesnt lay it on too thick.

text:
UPDATED: JUN 13, 2005 2,5 years old.
Opaque black with beige thin head.
Coffee aroma with notes of olives, demerara sugar, malt, chocolate and fruit.
Roasted flavor with notes of coffee, pears, fruits and salt. Sweet and dry with low bitterness.

Almost black; firm alcohol in the nose with currants, raisins, milk chocolate; smooth palate with a milky, raisiny character and a dry finish.  Well balanced, like a poor swedish mans version of Old Rasputin.

Dark, almost black color.  Huge delicate aroma of sweet soft milk chocolate.  The milk chocolate tastes carry into the palate followed by a robust malt and roast backbone.  Very smooth, great velvety mouthfeel.  Huge flavor for a alcohol presence so small.  Thanks Oakes.
A bit too weak for the style. I prefer more potent Imperials.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2006 When you get the unfiltered version it is beyond doubt a world classic. But as that is usually impossible the bottled version is a good substitute. Black. Chewy, full bodied. Complex with salty licquorice aroma. Nice bitterness. 
While the first vintage was mindblowing subesequent vintages has failed to meet my very high expectations. The score has thus been lowered from (9/5/10/4/19 = 4.7)
Few head. Aroma of flowers and liquorice. Acidity, slightly too bitter.
fine long head; aroma: coffee, ginger bread, complex; flavor: some beginning acidity, strong alcohol presence, coffee; deep bitter aftertaste - well-balanced
Just a shade less than the great Guinness so no poetry for this one.
